“On a match day, Troy is your leader, a big motivator and not only does he do his talking in the changing room, he delivers more occasions than not on the pitch. He is a key influencer in the group and his biggest qualities are not just as a player, but as an individual around the club and the way he drives the training and sets the standards. He is very well respected in the group and you don't just get that – you earn it over time. He's been an incredible player for the club and he's still got years left in him. He's a huge asset to the club.”
Strong words for the captain Troy Deeney from Graham Stack 💛

“The players are working very hard. You can see some of them on social media. I'm very happy with the guys and their fitness is evolving very, very well. We wanted to decrease the load this week as you cannot increase the intensity all the time without stopping. We are playing with the load after a period of continuous exercise. They have worked very hard for three weeks so we have changed the volume and frequency of the training sessions. We really educating them on how to pass through the days.”
A fitness update on the squad from Fitness Coach Victor Cervera 🗣️

“I made my debut for Jamaica a good few years ago now and I’ve had a couple of World Cup campaigns, and we should have done a lot better than we did. It’s all a great experience, you’re going to some of the other Caribbean islands or some of the central American teams and straight away you can see it’s a different culture in every place you go. It’s new experiences and you just have to try to take all of those experiences in. You get to go to places I probably otherwise wouldn’t have been to in my lifetime, and I’m thankful for all of those experiences.”
Adrian Mariappa loves the Golden Boys and the Reggae Boyz 🐝🇯🇲

“I find it quite positive being at home because I spend a lot of time with my kids and my wife. Every morning when I go to the room of my son and spend 5-10 minutes with him after he wakes up, for me it’s the best moment in life. So I try to take the positives from this.”
Christian Kabasele, family man 💛

Get well soon, Geri 💛

“The surgery was really good. It was difficult surgery as the meniscus was really bad. The first six weeks were hard, but since I left the hospital, I have been working two times a day. The first two months are important with that type of injury, with the extension of the leg and flexing the most important thing. Then you have to build more muscle in that leg as the muscle has completely gone. In 10 to 12 days, I can start doing the bike and walking and leave the crutches! I am happy at that and looking forward to every day.”
Gerard Deulofeu on the road to recovery 🙌

“Despite being far away, I always follow the club closely. I watch all the matches televised on ESPN or DAZN, I’m always on top of news and what’s going on behind the scenes, for example, signings, departures, tactical aspects, player and team technique, press conferences with players and the manager and I interact a lot with fellow Brazilian Watford fans. I also spend time learning more about the club’s history and significant past fixtures.”

💛 Find out about the amazing work of Healing Hands - Helping the NHS to heal!
Healing Hands - Helping the NHS to heal
April 2 at 1:36 PM ·
The amazing NHS angels are struggling!!
They spend 12 hour shifts in PPE, gloves and masks and are ending up with dry hands and faces......We want to help them any way possible!!
We are a small group of local ladies who have noticed a need for hand and face creams for the NHS staff.
We are asking our community to help us help our NHS!
Our aim is to provide drop boxes where the general public can drop off new, unused face or hand creams for the NHS staff which we can then take to the local hospitals.
It is such a simple idea but we really believe its a small way of saying thanks to all those amazing NHS angels.

One year on...
Relive a special day at Wembley as Gerard Deulofeu came off the bench to score twice as the Hornets beat Wolves 3-2 in extra time in the FA Cup semi-final.
Matt Doherty and Raul Jimenez had put Wolves 2-0 up and destined for the FA Cup Final, before Deulofeu's magical finish halved the deficit.
Troy Deeney then won and converted a 90th minute penalty, before Deulofeu completed an amazing comeback in extra-time to send the Hornets to their first FA Cup Final since 1984!
Watch the semi-final highlights in a cinematic recap!

💬 Craig Cathcart: “Away from football I like to focus on my family as I find it takes your mind away from the game. I used to do things like playing on the PlayStation quite a lot but it’s just not possible when you’ve got three kids running around different places. My kids are two, six and seven and my oldest daughter was only two when we moved down to Watford so this feels like home more than anywhere else to us as a family. They love their school and they have a lot of friends here, so we’re really settled. When I find time I do like watching other sports, especially boxing. I also watch snooker every now and then when it’s on. I recently bought a VR headset to try and the kids really like some of the games on there, so I do get to do a little bit of game-playing too!
How have you been keeping your little Hornets busy whilst at home?

"I saw the video that Fozzy was involved in and I just thought it was fantastic. You look at the overall situation in the Premier League and our fight is still far from over. When the season returns, indeed if it restarts, we've got to try and pick up where we left off, remain positive and build on that camaraderie and that sprit is very, very important. You can't underestimate the power of positive people and togetherness.”
Nigel Pearson 💛

I was very young when me and my family left the Democratic Republic of Congo but as I was growing up my parents told me almost everything about the difficulties of living there. It was impossible for us, so we moved to Belgium. It was not an easy decision for them to take because they left a lot of family behind, but they thought first of all about us and I thank them every day for that. My grandmother and aunts and most of my family are still there. I still follow the political situation there because even if I’m not living there, it is still my home country. It’s in my plan to go back there some day but I haven’t found the right moment to do so yet.
From DR Congo to Watford via Belgium, Christian Kabasele has a remarkable story 🇨🇩🇧🇪💛

💬 “The club have done a really good job, to be honest. About 10-12 days ago when it was looking as though this situation could be likely, they delivered equipment to our houses so we could set up home gyms and then they set up programmes for us. It’s been pretty self-explanatory. I do a lot of work on the bike, probably an hour every morning, and then some days I’ll do some strength work or go out for a run. The club have done a really good job to make sure it’s as easy as possible for the players to do the work to keep fit.”
Tom Cleverley lets us know how he's keeping fit at home 💪

📻 The View From the Vic' is the brand new official Watford FC podcast!
Each week, host Jon Marks will be joined by special guests including current first team stars, club legends and Hornets fans for exclusive interviews. Hear stories you will have never heard before to get a unique insight into life inside The Vic from years gone by...
...and what a line up for the first ever episode! Jon catches up with club captain Troy Deeney, goalkeeping coach Graham Stack, WFC record goal scorer Luther Blissett and club media consultant and lifelong Hornets fan Kevin Affleck. The group discuss how they are coping with the social distancing restrictions, what they are missing most about football, and look back at some great moments from the Golden Boys' history.
DON'T MISS OUT ⤵️

“One thing that really helps me relax is cooking. Some people find it stressful but I love it. You just need a glass of red wine or a gin and tonic of some sort, and after a few sips of that you just take your time and enjoy it. It’s as simple as that.
“I always do the cooking at home. It’s just nice most of the time to have that peace and quiet for about 20 minutes in the kitchen. In the summer I have the barbecue out at every opportunity and I love it.
“There was a rumour flying around that I designed our own house, but that’s not really true. We bought the house and renovated it, and the only bit I was interested in was the kitchen. It’s my wife’s house and she was making the decisions, but as long as I get my kitchen that’ll do me!”
Ben Foster 👨‍🍳

💬 “My idol when I was growing up was Buffon. I like his style and always looked to him. I was so happy when Italy won the World Cup and it would be great if I could achieve anything like he has achieved.” - Dan Bachmann

text:
💬 “We have sent them a very basic programme which touches every single part of conditioning: strength, mobility and cardiovascular sessions. We have just made sure we have these basic programmes and then we are waiting for the meeting of the Premier League and knowing exactly what will be happening over the next few days and weeks. If the situation changes, we will approach things in a different way.”
- Fitness Coach Victor Cervera on how the squad are keeping fit whilst working from home 🏋️‍♂️

ℹ️ Watford FC fully supports the Premier League’s decision to suspend fixtures due to the coronavirus outbreak.
“First and foremost, our concern is for the wellbeing of everybody connected with our club; players, staff and supporters,” said Hornets’ Chairman & CEO Scott Duxbury.
“Our actions in recent weeks to take extra precautionary steps reflect the fact that this has always been our priority; something our Head Coach Nigel Pearson reiterated fully at this morning’s press conference.”
He added: “We will continue our usual lines of communication with our supporters, providing the most up-to-date information possible.”

“We've had players who have had symptoms of not being well. We've got one player awaiting tests results on his symptoms. We are trying to be proactive and hopefully the Premier League will make a strong decision based on what is good for everybody. “We have to make sure the well-being of everybody concerned is taken care of first and foremost.”
Nigel Pearson gives his thoughts on the current Coronavirus situation as he takes part in his usual pre-match press conference.

💬 “We had such an amazing performance in our last home game against Liverpool. It was not the type of game we were expected to win but we believed in our hearts that we could do it, and we did. Before the game we said, ‘we have nothing to lose, we need to give everything, stay focused and then we’ll see’. We really have to focus now on Leicester and try to win our remaining games, especially the ones at home. Beating Liverpool was not the big achievement – that will come on May 17th if we stay in the Premier League.”
- Étienne Capoue

💬 Will Hughes: “You can't look at it and say we need a certain amount of points or we'll pick up points there or pick points here. We are going into every game looking to win it and that's the mentality we all have. Things change week by week, teams pick up results when you wouldn't expect them to, so you do have to take it game by game. The fans play such a big part.”

IT'S ALL OVER!! Two goals from Ismaïla Sarr and one from captain Troy Deeney earn us a massive win against the league leaders!

JUST WOW....😲
Deeney strikes Sarr's lay-off over Alisson first time and we're 3-0 up with 20 minutes to go!
THERE'S A SARR MAN...🇸🇳

IT'S TWO!!! 😆
Sarr races through, keeps his cool, and lofts the ball over Alisson to make it 2-0 Watford!

SARR SCORES!!! 😍
Doucouré plays across the face of goal to Sarr, who converts from close range and we're 1-0 up!
Goalless at the break but we've been the better side, with Deulofeu, Doucouré and Deeney all going close 💪

To mark Football vs Homophobia Month, the Proud Hornets supporters’ group are delighted to announce that current club captains Troy Deeney and Helen Ward have agreed to become their patrons 🏳️‍🌈
💬 Deeney: “I’m pleased to become a patron for the Proud Hornets and to be an ally for our fans from the LGBT community. For me, this shows our club is once again leading the way in its work with equality and diversity and it was an honour to be asked.”
💬 Ward: “I’m delighted to accept the Proud Hornets’ invitation to become their patron. It’s so important that we continue to stand together as one club and promote a united front against every type of discrimination.”

🗣️ Abdoulaye Doucouré: “Everyone remembers the France team that had so much success in World Cup 1998 and Euro 2000. We had amazing players like Zidane, Deschamps and Henry, but my favourite of them all was Patrick Vieira. He’s my favourite ever midfielder. I looked up to him because while I was growing up, I watched him playing for the national team and Arsenal and he was a great example for me to follow. He could do everything; he was the perfect midfielder. As a player I want to have the presence and influence on games like he had. I want to become one of the best midfielders, and there is nobody better than him to follow.” 🇫🇷
Who was your footballing idol when you were young?

“When I left Metz to go to Rennes, I used to watch loads of videos of Sadio Mané. It's true. I watched how he accelerates, how he dribbles, all of it.

I remember in one of our recent games I had a very good performance but afterwards she had a little bit of a cold and it made me sad. “It was always a dream to play in the Premier League and Watford gave me this opportunity.

I was just trying to get to know everybody really quickly in that first week, the players and the staff. The results make a difference to the outlook, but Nigel and I are quite balanced when we win and when we lose. We weren't sure what to expect but we just had to give it our best shot and be honest and open with everybody and then what will be will be. We knew there was talent in this squad and I've been pleased rather than surprised with the amount of points we have picked up. There is a lot to play for.”
🙌 Craig Shakespeare 🙌

“We are in a very positive frame of mind and we know the situation we are in. We would take the point given the circumstances of the game, but we have got to keep on improving on ourselves and as a team.
“The manager has tried to keep the message that the results don’t matter, to keep our feet on the ground and stay humble. We know the situation we are in and we are working hard every day to try and improve.”
Nathaniel Chalobah 💬
Your Sportsbet.io Man of the Match yesterday was Ismaïla Sarr 👏🇸🇳

“I've seen our side put in an incredibly honest and hard-working performance. Maybe another day I'm sitting here talking about winning three points but it's a hard-fought game when we've had our share of defending to do as well. What today tells me is that we've got a group of players who are doing everything they possibly can for this football club to put in performances and get results.”
Nigel Pearson 💬

Team spirit, everyone working hard for each other. The spirit in the team is great, there's lads on the bench coming in and contributing. Pussetto's clearance is almost as good as a goal for us, it was a great position for him to take up. This unbeaten home run is massive for us, we've just got to keep it going.”
Craig Dawson 💪

“Will Hughes has done some training. He has been with us today, just modified, so won't be in contention for the weekend. “I really enjoy playing alongside Étienne in midfield. At the beginning of my time at Watford it was more of a competition between the two of us because I wanted to get a place in the team, but we’ve been playing together for two or three years now and we spend a lot of time together too. We have different qualities because we are different midfielders – he can do some things I can’t, and I can do the same for him – and we learn all the time from each other. He has a lot of experience playing in England as well as back in France, so it’s impossible not to learn from him. It’s nice we also have players like Chalobah and Hughes coming in and playing well and we have a good relationship between all the midfielders, which is good for competition.” - Abdoulaye Doucouré 💬

“When I was five years old in 1998 the World Cup came to France and even though I was so young, it turned out to be something that really inspired me. The World Cup final, when we beat Brazil, is the first game I can remember watching on TV as a child and all my family were there. I can still remember the people outside in the city celebrating the victory and all the celebrations on the Champs-Élysées. All the French people were so happy and the team’s performance inspired a lot of people because we had a bright future ahead. From then on, I always watched football and I had a lot of posters in my bedroom, so it had a big impact on me.” - Abdoulaye Doucouré 🇫🇷
What's your first footballing memory? Let us know in the comments below 👇

What are Nigel Pearson and Nathaniel Chalobah saying to each other?

“I’m very excited to get to know Roberto Pereyra because even though I don’t know him personally, many people have said very good things about him as a person, and as a player he’s very renowned. I look forward to getting to know not only him but also the whole team.
“I already know Ben Wilmot, Ken Sema and Marvin Zeegelaar and I know Stefano Okaka was here too. Everyone talks very well about the club and the people who work at the training ground. The important thing now is for me to get settled in and get into the squad as soon as possible.”
Ignacio Pussetto is coming already very well connected at Vicarage Road 🇦🇷

ℹ️ Today's postponed Emirates FA Cup third round replay with Tranmere Rovers will now take place on Thursday, January 23 at 7.45pm.
A statement from The FA read: “After consultation with all the relevant parties, in order to keep the Competition on track and reduce the risk of causing fixture disruption elsewhere, the match has been rescheduled for Thursday January 23, 7.45pm kick-off.
“The winner of this tie will host Wolverhampton Wanderers or Manchester United in the Fourth Round Proper on Sunday 26 January, 3.00pm kick-off, live on BT Sport.”

We're pleased to announce the permament signing of Argentinian winger Ignacio Pussetto from Udinese Calcio 1896.
The versatile 24-year-old, who can also operate as a striker or an attacking midfielder, has agreed terms on a four-and-a-half-year contract.
Welcome Ignacio 🙌

Tonight's Emirates FA Cup third round replay against Tranmere Rovers has been postponed, following heavy rainfall from Storm Brendan at Prenton Park since Sunday.
Both clubs were in regular contact with each other, the referee and the Football Association over the past two days, discussing the options available.
However, following a pitch inspection this afternoon, the referee decided the match unfortunately could not go ahead.
The date for the rescheduled match will follow as soon as possible.

“It's our next game, we want to win it and we had the opportunity to do that at home and we didn't see the job through. It's unfortunate we were unable to finish the job off first time round. We give them credit because they showed lot of spirt in the second half. It's an opportunity for both sides to progress and we are going to make sure the team out there is picked with the view to players getting pitch exposure. A number of players have been limited with game-time this season so it will be useful for them. Young players will also get an opportunity, so it's good for them, too.” 💬
All 👀 on tonight's FA Cup clash with Tranmere Rovers for the boss.

He was an inspirational man but not just for football people but for people that came into contact with him. He's definitely looking down and giving us a little kick up the backside to make sure we do it right – and we see Rita at games all the time.
“The word legend can be used too often but he is definitely a Watford legend. As players, you have to realise what someone has done and to move forward we have to acknowledge the past. As players we appreciate we wouldn't be in this position without him and we are just trying to move the legacy forward.”
There's only one Graham Taylor 💛

text:
“I grew up in Freetown, Sierra Leone, but I don’t really have many memories from back then. I went back there this summer and it was just an eye opener; there’s real poverty over there. I hear some of the stories and my Dad tells me bits and pieces here and there. I moved to England when I was seven and football made the move easier. I spoke Krio, which is kind of broken English, so I could speak fluent English pretty quickly. I would always go and find a football at break times at school and play with my mates. When people started to comment on my ability it made me more confident and I grew as a person.”
From Sierra Leone to Watford, it's been an incredible journey for Nathaniel Chalobah 🇸🇱🏴󠁧󠁢󠁥󠁮󠁧󠁿

“Success just needs to work hard and get in the team. If you don't work hard there is no way to get in the team. There is a new manager here and he has to work hard to get in the team. He needs to give everything and work hard to improve himself. He's got everything, I told him that. He is so big and strong, he keeps the ball and can score goals. He is from the same city in Nigeria where I came from in Benin City. He needs to be disciplined and show that you deserve to play and needs to get angry when he isn't playing. The sky should be the limit for him. He needs to help keep the team in the Premier League.”

“The players have been terrific. The idea when you come in as a new management team is to have an impact and get results. You are never quite sure if it will work but we have had a positive impact. We are also aware that it's only the start. We have to maintain the confidence, the belief and the desire. We have to push on as we want to climb the table.”
Craig Shakespeare 🗣️

It's time to place your votes for Sportsbet.io Player of the Month!
There's been some incredible performances but you can only choose one!
Let us know your choice ⤵️

“We may be in the relegation zone but we want to send a message that it will be very difficult to get points at Vicarage Road. We got back-to-back wins. Now it's about keeping focus and going game by game. We are in a difficult situation but if we keep going like this, we are going to get out of the situation.”
Étienne Capoue 💬

Watford vs Aston Villa FC
💛🖤 The Graham Taylor Derby 💜💙
We found out from the fans of both clubs just what the great man means to them...

“You can't expect fans to pay their hard-earned money and come here and be great all the time when we lose. They've got a right to hammer us when we have been bad. We have been bad at times but it's up to the players to create the atmosphere. The fans want to see hard work and people fighting for the shirt. If you chase a ball down, if you win a tackle you weren't meant to or win a header, it gets the crowd involved.
“They've seen that in the last few weeks and the atmosphere has gone through the roof. We need to make this a fortress and a hard place to play. We've got a massive foundation [to build on] and we've still got Cleverley and Welbeck, players of this nature, to come back. We are a proper outfit.”

“He feels very good, he's adapted very well now and we are here to support him. It was difficult when he arrived and he was not playing in his position but when he is on the right wing and can express himself, you can see what a player he is.”
Who else loves Ismaïla Sarr as much as Étienne? 🇸🇳

It's been 24 hours so it’s time to re-live it all over again!
Three goals.
Three points.
What an incredible day at Vicarage Road! 😍

Who gets your vote for Sportsbet.io Man of the Match this afternoon?
Let us know 👇

WHAT A DAY AT THE VIC!
ABSOLUTE SCENES AT FULL TIME 🙌

Ten-man Watford see off Villa with a Deeney double and Sarr's strike!

67: Deeney 👊
71: Sarr 🙌

It's three! 😍
Sarr lashes in Capoue's cross first-time after a swift counter-attack and 10-man Watford are three goals to the good!

One game to go...
2019 ⌛
2020 ⏳
Who's ready?

Abdoulaye Doucouré says the Hornets are really looking forward to playing Aston Villa FC in a Premier League six-pointer 💪
Watford won at Vicarage Road for the first time in the league this season against Manchester United last Sunday, and the Frenchman is pleased the home supporters have that winning feeling back 🙌

🗓️ April 30, 2016
🆚 Watford 3-2 Aston Villa FC
🔢 Gomes (GK), Paredes (Berghuis 57'), Cathcart, Britos, Anya, Abdi, Suarez, Watson, Jurado (Amrabat 71'), Deeney (C), Ighalo
⚽ Abdi (45'), Deeney (90', 90+3')
The last time we faced the Villans...

“Sheffield United were not fifth by accident. They are a good side, it’s really difficult to deal with their overlapping centre-backs. I think we did well most of the time, even if Ben had to save us a couple of times.
“It’s good to know that you have the goalkeeper who can help you when it’s difficult. Some moments were really difficult but we relied on Ben to keep us in the game and it’s good to have everybody involved in this battle.”
Christian Kabasele 💬

“We were quite comfortable in the first half. It swung in their favour a bit later though. Our boys have had a different mentality though recently. It's a tough place to come to and if we now go and beat Villa it's a good point.”
The skipper, Troy Deeney 💬
Who is your Sportsbet.io Man of the Match this afternoon? 📊

“You just have to look at our last three matches, and the fight and determination. We've got lots of skills and ability, we just need to transfer it onto the pitch. If we keep that going with that confidence we’ve got a chance. I just like to keep plugging away and go under the radar. Long may that continue.”
Super Ben Foster 🗣️

The magic man opens the scoring! 🙌
Deulofeu races clear of the Blades' backline and beats keeper Henderson at his near post to make it 1-0 with 27 minutes played.

Boxing Day was made for football 💪
Destination: Sheffield United

“Sheffield United is a perfect game. You can't go there thinking it's going to be a nice game of football. It's going to be horrible, it's going to be cold, they are going to run all over you, they are going to kick you. If you don't match that, you lose the game. It's that simple. If you match it and have a bit more guile and be a bit street smart, you can win the game.”
The skipper has his plan ready for Sheffield United tomorrow 💪

The boss has a special Christmas message for you all...
🗣🎅

“I want collective buy-in. I hope we have got it – not just from the players, from everyone who works for the club as they will contribute in some way. It's clearly about the players and putting performances in. I've seen some encouraging signs in the last couple of weeks. We have got to make ground on sides and we need to get some momentum at some point. The last few performances have been encouraging. It was a big win on Sunday and now we've got some really key games coming up.”
Players ✅
Coaches ✅
Staff ✅
Fans ✅
The boss knows we are all in this together 💪

🚨 ACCESS ALL AREAS INSIDE THE VlCARAGE ROAD TUNNEL 🚨
Find out exactly what happens inside the tunnel at a Premier League game with this fascinating insight into the win over Manchester United!

“We've beaten Manchester United at home and they are the biggest club in the world, we've beaten them on our patch. We can't get carried away, that's the standard now and you can't drop it when we play Villa at home. You have to keep that level of consistency. This gaffer isn't going to pull any punches. He has come in and all the nonsense has stopped. We've stopped feeling sorry for ourselves and started working together and I think that's what got us over the line today. It's been two weeks of hard work. It's easy to sit and sulk but we haven't done that.”
The skipper, Troy Deeney 💪

“I came through the Academy since the age of nine and I want to see the best for this club, when I’m wearing the shirt or when I’m not playing, I’ll be supporting the lads as best I can so we can try to get the wins to try to stay in the league.
“It’s very realistic and I’ve got full faith and belief that we can come through the other end. I’ve been in worse situations and when I was at Crystal Palace the team there was nowhere near what we’ve got here, and we finished in mid-table. So I’ve got full belief we will turn this around.”
Adrian Mariappa has been there and done it before 💪🗣️

“The last couple of weeks we really dug in. Last week was the turning point, from the first minute we were on it, trying to do the right things. The boss wants everyone to dig in, fight & work. We've had plenty to go against us, so it's nice for a little bit of luck for us for a change. Hopefully it's a starting point, and we can gain a lot of confidence and go into the Christmas games with renewed optimism now.”
Ben Foster 💬

🎥 HIGHLIGHTS 🎥
It's time to relive a fantastic afternoon at Vicarage Road 🙌
Enjoy!

“I thought Hughes was brilliant today and he was last week as well. Last time I saw Will was at Derby, he’s matured fantastically well as a player and as a person. I’m not usually one for singling out individuals but as he’s been brought up, I’m really pleased to be able to say I thought he was really, really good today.”
The boss was impressed with Will Hughes today, were you?

On this day four years ago...

“We are fully aware of the danger we are in, the precarious nature of our status if we don't rectify it sooner rather than later. It's time for myself to keep a calm outlook in how we navigate our way through. I'm not going to put a greater level of anxiety on the players by highlighting the position we are in. We are reminded of that on a daily basis. We've got to get some clarity on how we work that allows players to go out and perform.”
Who else loves the way Nigel Pearson speaks? 🗣️
João Pedro has arrived at the training ground to meet some of his new teammates...🤝

“I wasn't thinking about winning. It never really crossed my mind as I was focussed on the team, playing well and playing as many games as I could. It was, of course, nice to be recognised when you are doing well – that award was just the icing on the cake. I got Players' Player the year before so it was nice to get the big one. I didn't expect it and didn't even have a speech rehearsed – I just said whatever came to me in that moment. I was very grateful to receive the award as a lot of hard work had gone in to reach point and a lot of obstacles had to be overcome. It was an extremely proud moment.”
Adrian Mariappa discusses winning the coveted Player of the Season award at the end of the 2011/12 campaign 🏆

Gerard Deulofeu 🗣️

We know it's a tough league and the boys haven't started well but there is room for improvement.”

“Back home every is watching. They follow players who move to teams and they support the players wherever they go. When I moved to Reading, they became Reading fans. Fans in Nigeria support Watford because of Odion, Isaac and Tom and they want to know the result of Watford. They want to know how their Nigerian brothers are doing. These players can make fans back home happy with how they play in the Premier League.”

“He's a leader, he demands respect off everyone and once he's got that respect, he fully gives you the respect back. There are obviously a few things he needs to sort out but I think he will do really well.
“He is 100 percent no-nonsense, no-one will be stepping out of line, no-one will be allowed to disrupt the dressing room, but I'd describe him as a soft, gentle giant. He gives you that love, that respect, will have a laugh and a joke but he'll want plenty back. If you respect Nigel and work hard, you'll do well under him.”
Club legend Paul Robinson on the appointment of Nigel Pearson 💬

We are pleased to confirm the appointment of Nigel Pearson as Head Coach on a contract that runs initially until the end of this season.
Watford’s Chairman & CEO Scott Duxbury said: “Nigel is an impressive coach and comes with all of the experience and success we believe can have a very positive impact on our season.
“It’s been a pleasure spending time listening to the passion with which he talks about the game. His enthusiasm, organisation and motivation will I’m certain prove essential in driving the team forwards and upwards over the coming weeks and months.”

🌈 Proud Hornets co-founder Callum Jewell meets with club captains Troy Deeney and Helen Ward for an informal conversation about their own personal experiences of discrimination in football, as well as the Premier League's Rainbow Laces campaign and Watford FC’s We campaign.

“For us there are loads of positives to take. We’ll be taking loads of bits from that game and trying to build on them. I said to them at the end that if they show that same fight, that same drive and that same commitment and professionalism right until the end of the season, I’m sure we’ll be in a very good place.”

An open letter from Quique Sánchez Flores to the Watford FC family -
“I would love to say a big thank you from my heart for the appreciation, respect and support that I’ve felt in each moment I’ve lived in the lovely family that Watford FC is.
This is not the time to think about individual feelings, it’s time to have a collective reaction.
Peacefully, for having taken the risk needed for someone and something I love: Watford FC and football.
Hope, passion, fight, commitment, effort, hard work and luck.
Drop by drop, until we achieve it.
I wish you all the best. Stay strong!
You’ll always be in my heart.
Quique Sánchez Flores”
💛

“Playing in that it didn’t feel like a 3-0. First half I thought it was quite even but we were defending well, we were quite comfortable and I thought we were in the ascendency as well. Up to that point before conceding the first goal I thought we were dealing with them very well. We have to go back to the drawing board now, look at the game and work hard for next week.”
Adrian Mariappa reflects on yesterday's disappointing defeat 💬
The skipper's back 💪

Goalless at the break but the Hornets are on top, Pope saving well from Deulofeu twice.

“It’s so important having Troy Deeney back in the squad. It’s good that he’s back and hopefully the other injured players can also come back soon so that we can have a full squad and go from there, because we’re much stronger with everyone fit. We know all about Troy, he’s important, he’s a vocal guy and he’s the captain so it’s good to have him around again. I don’t think I’ve ever had a teammate before who has been at the same club for almost 10 years – that’s a long time in football! He is really important for the club and to play an entire decade here just proves that. It’s good for him and good for the club. He is the face of Watford.”
Daryl Janmaat is happy to see the skipper back amongst it, are you? 💪

“I definitely have aspirations to play international football at any level, to have that experience would be great. I qualify to play for Jamaica through my grandparents. I've not been to Jamaica for a while, but I love it there and it's a country that means a lot to me. I’d love to one day follow in the footsteps of Mariappa and win as many caps as possible.”
Dante Baptiste on his ambitions to join the long list of Hornets to have played for Jamaica 🇯🇲

“We don’t have time in football, it passes really quick. Modern football has changed a lot. It’s all about results now. Winning is a vitamin for everyone, players have energy & want to play again.”
- Quique Sanchez Flores 💬💪

text:
“I buy boots one size bigger as they are the only boots I could find for 10 pounds. It sounds weird, but it's real. My feet hurt a lot, I had to put them in ice when I got in from work as it was so, so painful.“
I was so, so bad. I didn't sleep well. I was so stressed. I was anxious a lot. I broke my [front] teeth through grinding in the night. I missed my dog. I couldn't see my parents and my partner was working the night shifts at Pret a Manger as she was studying during the day as we needed more money. It was so hard. One day, I said, 'I need to change, even if we have less money, even if we just pay the bills and nothing else. I don't care. I can't sleep 20 hours a week. I'm sorry.'”
Head to watfordfc.com to read the full incredible and inspiring story of Watford FC Ladies star, Andrea Carid 15 - SPI ❤️

“We feel a bit unlucky not to come away with a win on the night, if the penalty went in who knows how the game would have gone. It shows how far we’ve come as a team, pushing the likes of Holland and Germany all the way in the games and feeling a bit disappointed not to come away with a win.
“It leaves us in a playoff position and we are full of confidence knowing we can compete against the top nations, who will ultimately be going to the tournament thinking they can win it.”
Craig Cathcart's Northern Ireland pushed the Dutch all the way and claimed a 0️⃣-0️⃣ draw which meant they had to settle for a play-off spot if they are to qualify for next summer's UEFA EURO 2020 🏆

“My mum is actually Jamaican and my dad is Bermudian. They live in Bermuda; my whole family lives in Bermuda. I have a couple of cousins out here but they live far away from me. My whole family is out in Bermuda and they come whenever they can.
“I’d probably say one of my idols is Nahki Wells, he's playing for QPR and doing really well right now. Also, Shaun Goater. He did really well during his time at Manchester City. It’s probably them main two because they’ve basically put Bermuda on the map for us. Nahki is still doing that until this day and he’s given me advice throughout my career so far and he’s a good person to look up to. I aspire to be like him one day.”
Kane Crichlow adding to a strong list of names putting Bermudian football on the map 🇧🇲

“When you're a victim of racist abuse on the football pitch you feel really angry because it's so unfair to be treated like this just because you are black. I’m really pleased the club is taking a stand not only against racism but against every type of discrimination, because whatever form it takes, it is unacceptable. This is only the start, but I'm sure that by working with the police we will get more results and find people who are responsible.”
- Christian Kabasele 🗣
#BuzzOff #watfordfc Herts Police

Ben Foster give his honest opinions after Watford 1-2 Chelsea in the Premier League.
The former England goalkeeper almost scored an injury-time equaliser against Frank Lampard's side, and says he's not a fan of VAR despite the technology giving Watford a penalty.

"I understand the reaction of the fans because they're frustrated like we are. I would like to make every single substitution the fans would love but we won't always agree. Let's make sure there is always the positive energy that we get at the start of the games. The players have to create these moments for themselves, of course, but everyone can help. Between fans and players we have an amazing team and the positive energy from both can help us."
- Quique Sánchez Flores 🗣
The Hornets came close to salvaging a draw and threw everyone forward at the death, but goalkeeper Foster's header was saved in injury time.
It wasn't the start we hoped for but the Hornets have grown into the half and came close to levelling the scores through Deulofeu. Come on you 'Orns! 🐝💪

"The intensity and speed of the game is much faster than we play. We thought it would be a good experience for the boys to play against an English team.
Watford were very competitive, they have a lot of decent players who will have a bright future and they play a modern game, nothing like the old English way to play. We thought it would be a tough match as I've seen the evolution of English teams. Watford are a good team. The Academy facilities at Watford are fantastic, the level of the pitches, the quality of the grass and then the Dome. It's just fantastic."
Rogelio Andrade, SE Palmeiras Youth Coach 🇧🇷

text: “We don’t deserve this with this group of players, we have trained well and we showed what we can do. But that’s football, we have to improve every day and next time we are going to take the best decision and hopefully win.” - Gerard Deulofeu 🇪🇸

“It's very difficult to play against this team. The stadium is tough and this is a tough team, but we didn't concede the match. We have very clear chances, a little bit less than them but we played the match we expected. Conceding the goal we did is a little bit hard but this is possible in the position we are in.
“Now we need to create a balance between the feelings about nearly winning and drawing. It is not too bad and we can improve. I know our players believe in their work.”
Quique Sanchez Flores 🗣️

“It’s been a strange start to the season. On a personal level I’m pleased to be back out there after the injuries I’ve suffered over the past year or two. I think having a full pre-season was massively important for me to get that foundation of fitness, so I was glad to be able to do the full six weeks.
“It was always my target to get into the team and to stay there. I’ve had a decent run of games so far, but next up I want to continue to do the best I can for the team and hopefully that can contribute to getting results. I’m pleased to be back amongst it and more involved than last year, but I’m obviously really disappointed about the results.” - Tom Cleverley

Adalberto Peñaranda is all set to continue his football journey with a loan spell at KAS Eupen.
A reminder below of just where it all started for the Venezuela international 🇨🇴
“When I was 17 I got shot in the leg,” he said. “I was in a friend’s house in Barrio with a few other football players and we were just chatting when these guys came in with weapons and just started shooting us.
“My friend [Charlys Ortiz] was shot in the arm and I was shot in the leg. The bullet went through here [the inside of his left leg] and out here [the lower left side of his thigh]. It was a very painful moment.
“I was lucky it wasn't a big injury. I went to the hospital and there was a lot of blood. They cleaned the wound, I had anti-inflammatory tablets and bandages – no surgery. That was it. Fortunately, it didn’t touch the muscle.”

Premier League performance? Cardiff at home? Wolves away? Cardiff away? There's too many 🤩

🇧🇷✈🔜
Ahead of Brazilian teenager João Pedro's much-anticipated arrival at Watford in January of this upcoming season, who better to check out Vicarage Road first than his mother and step-father 👫
And that's exactly what they did on Monday June 10 on a typical English summer's day; cold, wet and overcast 🌧
But that couldn't dampen the spirits of Flavia and Carlos as they looked around a stadium busy with close-season development works, stopping for a panoramic photo on the balcony of The Gallery restaurant 🏟
Flavia even tried to Facetime her son to show him where he'll be wowing the Vicarage Road faithful in just over six months' time, however a quick check of the watch confirmed he'd be out on the training field with current club Fluminense ⚽🏃
So it's not quite welcome João Pedro time yet - but it's very much a case of a warm welcome to his family from the Watford family! 🤗💛

"It's so great, I feel so grateful to be in this club, in this team."

text: Where in the world will you be watching the @EmiratesFACup Final from? 🌎
Thank you India for your good wishes for our FA Cup Final #ImagineIf

Five eras!
Five squads!
But only one 5-a-side team!
Pick one player from each year and build your dream Watford team... 🤔

We've already had one special day at Wembley this season...
Take a look at the top 🔟 moments from that famous occasion!

#ImagineIf a young man caught up in the gang culture on the streets of his hometown could reach the FA Cup final.
Andre Gray has walked a path few have taken before him. Growing up looking over his shoulder, watching out for cars he didn’t recognise, to the life-changing moment he was stabbed in the face, the Watford striker has persevered through adversity.
Now he is days away from walking out in front of thousands of Hornets fans at the national stadium to try and help Watford land a first trophy in their history.
This is his story, in his own words.
#ImagineIf we showed Jose Holebas our Twitter mentions and got him to answer back...Well imagine no more!

Anyone who knows Watford, knows. We’ve had amazing highs, but all too often, they’re followed by equally painful lows.
Watch players, staff and fans talk through the great moments of 1984, 1999, 2006 and 2013 but then reflect on the difficult periods that followed each.
#ImagineIf, in 2019, things are different.
#ImagineIf we can end this chapter with the greatest moment in the Club’s history.

Looking for something to do to calm the pre-Final nerves? Fancy meeting a Hornets legend? 👀
Jay DeMerit has flown back to the UK for the big game & will be pulling pints at @craftbeershops in Little Chalfont’s FA Cup Final Party on Friday evening! 🍻
Don't miss the chance to meet Jay & enjoy some local craft beers from 6pm.
More Details ⤵
https://www.facebook.com/events/335654147151756/

text:
⚽ | A five-goal thriller ended with a late, late winner for #watfordfc.
#OnThisDay in 2015...

❌ | “At the time Manu Almunia was here, as well as Jonathan Bond and Jack Bonham. The club had so many players. Gianfranco said it wasn’t anything to do with my ability or my personality, I just couldn’t be brought in until some people went out.”
Head of Academy Goalkeeping Graham Stack has revealed he was once on trial at #watfordfc, but who do you think are the ones that got away⁉️

🔙 | “It's good to be back. It was my decision to play. I wanted to play and get some minutes because it's important to be sharp and be ready for the next game. I'm totally back now and feeling fine.”
Daryl Janmaat's on the comeback trail after playing 45 minutes for #watfordfc U23s on Friday.

FT | #watfordfc 0-3 Liverpool
Three goals in the game's latter stages inflict a harsh defeat on the Hornets, who had been well and truly in the game.
Thanks for your support today. Onto the next one - Leicester away next weekend 💪

🗣 | “We will not modify our style. We will be loyal to our style and play the way we usually do, but knowing we have to be careful with their players because they are very, very good.
“I expect a difficult game, a tough game. It's a good challenge for us. We are working hard to live this experience and enjoy the games. Playing at home we feel we are able to win all the games we play. I am sure playing home with the support of our fans it will be a different game.”
- Javi Gracia

💬 | “I think we have to be humble. Newcastle United has a very good squad, and are a very good team. Perhaps they have a lack of confidence because of their results, but they will react and I think we have to be ready to win there.”
- Abdoulaye Doucouré
#watfordfc

“I think we have to be humble.”
Abdoulaye Doucouré is still expecting a very difficult afternoon for #watfordfc against a struggling Newcastle United at St James' Park tomorrow.
See the full preview right here, exclusively on Facebook ⤵️

🗣 | “They are a good team, they have a very good coach. They are looking for their first win, they are working very hard to try to get it and we need to be ready for a difficult game, for a tough game. All the games they are playing they are playing with the option to get a better result. I am sure in the next game they will try again.”
- Javi Gracia

🛣 | “It taught me that success is a journey and not a destination, and there are different roads for me to get there. I understand a lot more now.”
- Michael Folivi

text:
🗣 | “She has been massive for me. It's hard to put into words what she did for me. I genuinely wouldn't be here if it wasn't for her. She pushed me, took me everywhere when I was too young to go by myself. It would have been easy for her not to take me or say she can't afford it, but she did what she had to do for me. She worked at a train station at one point and worked so she could pay for me to go where I needed to go.”
#watfordfc striker Andre Gray opens up about his family, his past, and his passions in an in-depth interview.

FT | #watfordfc 2-1 Crystal Palace
Three wins out of three for the Hornets!
Holebas' sublime curling effort wins it, with Pereyra having opened the scoring just after the break. Zaha pulled one back with 12 minutes remaining, but it was too little, too late for the visitors.
COME ON YOU 'ORNS!!!

HT | #watfordfc 0-0 Crystal Palace
Goalless at the break, but both sides have had their chances. Foster has denied Benteke and McArthur with good saves, while at the other end Hennessey kept out Pereyra's effort and Janmaat shot just wide moments before the break.

🎬 | Thanks for your support in 2017/18, #watfordfc fans!

#mondaymotivation 💪🏽

FULL-TIME | Manchester United 1-0 #watfordfc
The Hornets’ campaign ends in a narrow defeat at Old Trafford, with Rashford’s first half goal enough to separate the sides.
Watford finish the campaign in 14th place.
Listen live ➡️ watfordfc.com

🔢 | Manchester United v #watfordfc team news (3pm KO)
Three changes for the Hornets. Gomes, Deulofeu & Richarlison come in for Karnezis, Capoue & Deeney.
HORNETS | Gomes (GK) (C); Janmaat, Cathcart, Kabasele, Holebas; Doucouré, Hughes; Deulofeu, Pereyra, Richarlison; Gray.
Subs | Bachmann (GK), Prödl, Mariappa, Chalobah, Lukebakio, Sinclair, Deeney.
UNITED | Romero (GK); Darmian, Bailly, Rojo, Blind; Carrick (C), McTominay; Mata, Sanchez, Young; Rashford.
Subs | Pereira (GK), Jones, Shaw, Valencia, Herrera, Pogba, Lingard.
Listen live ⤵️

FULL-TIME | #watfordfc 2-1 Newcastle
First half Pereyra & Gray goals are enough as the Hornets hang on despite sustained Newcastle pressure late in the game. Perez scored the Magpies' goal early in the second-half.
Thanks for your excellent home support this afternoon, and throughout the season. Next up, we're at Manchester United next Sunday.
Listen live ⤵️
watfordfc.com

HALF-TIME | #watfordfc 2-0 Newcastle
An excellent first half display from the Hornets, who lead through Pereyra's second-minute strike and a Gray header midway through the half. It might have been three, but Deeney's penalty and subsequent follow-up were both saved by keeper Dubravka.

HALF-TIME | #watfordfc 1-0 Chelsea
The Hornets lead at the break thanks to Troy Deeney's 42nd-minute penalty, capping a fine first-half display for the hosts. Chelsea are down to 10 men after Tiemoue Bakayoko's sending off on the half-hour for a second bookable offence.
Listen live ➡️ watfordfc.com

🔢 | #watfordfc v Chelsea team news (8pm KO)
Two changes to the Hornets' starting XI. Janmaat & Zeegelaar both come in, while Kabasele & Cleverley make way (both hamstring). Deadline day signings Ndong (who has completed his three-game suspension) & Lukebakio are named on the bench, as is 18-year-old defender Joy Mukena.
HORNETS | Karnezis (GK); Mariappa, Prödl, Holebas; Janmaat, Doucouré, Capoue, Zeegelaar; Deulofeu, Deeney (C), Richarlison.
Subs | Bachmann (GK), Mukena, Ndong, Pereyra, Lukebakio, Carrillo, Gray.
BLUES | Courtois (GK); Azpilicueta, Luiz, Cahill (C); Moses, Bakayoko, Kante, Zappacosta; Willian, Hazard, Pedro.
Subs | Caballero (GK), Rudiger, Emerson, Drinkwater, Fabregas, Hudson-Odoi, Giroud.

FT | Everton 3-2 #watfordfc
The Hornets let a two-goal lead slip as they fall to a third successive defeat in the Premier League.
Watford were seemingly in control after Richarlison and Kabasele goals after the break, but the Toffees fought back through Niasse, Calvert-Lewin and an injury-time Baines penalty to seal all three points at Goodison Park.
There was nearly a late lifeline for the Hornets, but Cleverley dragged a penalty wide deep into stoppage time.

💬 | "We didn't deserve this result. I'm really proud how we played."
Marco Silva rues missed chances, but proud of his #watfordfc team's display at Stamford Bridge yesterday.
➡ http://bit.ly/2yZo7ZO

FT | Chelsea 4-2 #watfordfc
A final scoreline which was harsh on the Hornets.
After Doucoure cancelled out Pedro's opener on the stroke of half-time, Pereyra handed Watford a 2-1 lead shortly after the break.
The Hornets were left to rue missed chances - two fantastic opportunities in particular for Richarlison - as Batshuayi pulled Chelsea level and then Azpilicueta headed the hosts in front with three minutes to go.
Deep into injury-time, Batshuayi added a fourth, but this was no walkover for the Blues, who ultimately inflicted a first away defeat of the season on Watford.

FT | Swansea City 1-2 #watfordfc
A 90th-minute Richarlison winner completes Watford's third consecutive top-flight away win, a first in Hornets history!
The Brazilian scored one-on-one in the last minute to seal all three points, after Tammy Abraham's close-range effort on 56 minutes cancelled out Andre Gray's early opener.

HT | Swansea City 0-1 #watfordfc

FULL-TIME: Everton 1-0 #watfordfc
A 56th-minute Barkley strike settled affairs at Goodison Park. The England international found the bottom corner from 25 yards to inflict a fourth straight defeat on the Hornets.
Deeney and Okaka both went close after the break - the former turned Janmaat's cross wide at the near post, and the latter saw a clever turn and volley kept out by Everton keeper Robles.
A big thank you to the travelling Watford supporters who made their way north for tonight's game - safe journey home.
Matchday Live: www.watfordfc.com

HALF-TIME: Everton 0-0 #watfordfc
Goalless at the break, but Gomes has been the busiest of the two keepers. The Brazilian has been in fine form, denying Barkley, Jagielka and Davies during the opening 25 minutes.
Doucoure and Mariappa have both had chances for Watford, who lost Kabasele to injury late in the half, Zuniga coming on to take his place.
Matchday Live: www.watfordfc.com

Three points for the Hornets, who reach the magic 40-point mark with a hard-fought victory over the Swans!
Etienne Capoue's volleyed goal late in the first-half proved to be the winner, although substitute Stefano Okaka did have a sublime chest & volley ruled out for offside with 10 minutes to go.
Thanks for your excellent support this afternoon. Come on you 'Orns!!!

The Hornets lead through a 42nd-minute Etienne Capoue strike! The French midfielder dispossessed Alfie Mawson and first forced a save from Lukasz Fabianski, before rifling the rebound in off the post with his left peg.

FULL-TIME: #watfordfc 1-0 Sunderland
An important and deserved win for the Hornets, thanks to Miguel Britos' 59th minute goal. The defender headed home his first in Watford colours to secure all three points.
Today's attendance was 20,805. A big thank you for your superb support this afternoon, Hornets fans!
See you back here at The Vic on Tuesday for West Brom.
Matchday Live: www.watfordfc.com

HALF-TIME: #watfordfc 0-0 Sunderland
The Hornets have had the better of the chances, but it's goalless at the break.
Jordan Pickford has been by far the busiest of the keepers, denying M'Baye Niang, Abdoulaye Doucoure and Craig Cathcart attempts.
There was a late blow for Watford, who lost Younes Kaboul to what looked like a hamstring injury.

text:
FULL-TIME: Crystal Palace 1-0 #watfordfc
The Eagles took all three points at Selhurst Park, despite not registering a shot on target throughout. It was a Troy Deeney own goal which ultimately settled matters - the Hornets' captain headed into his own net from Yohan Cabaye's free-kick midway through the second-half.
Matchday Live: www.watfordfc.com

HALF-TIME: Crystal Palace 0-0 #watfordfc
An even first-half ends goalless at Selhurst Park. There's been little to trouble either keeper thus far, M'Baye Niang drawing a routine save from Wayne Hennessey 25 yards from goal, and Yohan Cabaye seeing a shot deflected wide at the other end after Younes Kaboul had headed away a Wilfried Zaha cross.
Matchday Live: www.watfordfc.com
Listen-in to live commentary of today's game against #CPFC now over at watfordfc.com FREE - just sign-in or sign-up 🐝⚽

FULL-TIME: #watfordfc 3-4 Southampton
Dusan Tadic and Nathan Redmond overturned Troy Deeney's fourth-minute volley to hand the Saints a 2-1 lead at the break.
Stefano Okaka converted Isaac Success' cross to equalise with 10 minutes to, but quickfire goals from Manolo Gabbiadini and Redmond effectively sealed all three points for the visitors.
Abdoulaye Doucoure tapped home his first Watford goal right at the death, but it was too little, too late for the Hornets.
Matchday Live: www.watfordfc.com

HALF-TIME: #watfordfc 1-2 Southampton
For the second weekend running, the Hornets were off to a flying start. Troy Deeney volleyed in Stefano Okaka's layoff to open the scoring in the fourth minute.
But the Saints bounced back through Dusan Tadic, who equalised on 28 minutes, then Nathan Redmond scored via the post in first-half stoppage time.
Matchday Live: www.watfordfc.com

Two changes for the Hornets after last weekend's draw with West Ham, Prödl and Okaka come in for the injured Janmaat and Zárate.

FULL-TIME: #watfordfc 1-1 West Ham
Honours even in the end at Vicarage Road. Troy Deeney handed the Hornets the lead with a third-minute penalty, after Mauro Zarate - who was later strechered off with a knee injury - had been fouled by Cheikhou Kouyate.
Sub Andre Ayew salvaged a point for the Hammers with 17 minutes to go, tapping into the empty net after Michail Antonio's shot hit both posts.
West Ham's Antonio was dismissed for a second booking on 86 minutes, but despite some late pressure the Golden Boys were unable to find the winning goal.
Matchday Live: www.watfordfc.com

HALF-TIME: #watfordfc 1-0 West Ham
Troy Deeney converted a third-minute penalty after Mauro Zarate had been tripped by Cheikhou Kouyate in the area, in what was an excellent start from the Hornets.
There was concern late on for Zarate though, who was stretchered off with what looked like a knee injury during stoppage time.
Abdoulaye Doucoure has been introduced as the ex-Hammer's replacement.
Matchday Live: www.watfordfc.com

💬 | "I’m very happy, we’ve had two important results, but it’s not finished."
M'Baye Niang speaks to watfordfc.com after netting his first goal in #watfordfc's 2-1 win over Burnley Football Club!
What did you make of Niang's performance today⁉️

FULL-TIME: #watfordfc 2-1 Burnley
Three more points for the Hornets! First-half headers from Troy Deeney and M'Baye Niang win it for Walter Mazzarri's side, who played against 10 men since the sixth minute after Jeff Hendrick's sending off for a two-footed tackle. Ashley Barnes pulled one back from the penalty spot with 12 minutes to go, but the Hornets held on and are now four unbeaten in the Premier League.
Matchday Live: www.watfordfc.com

📷🎯
A wonderful angle of M'Baye Niang's header that put #watfordfc 2-0 just prior to the break at Vicarage Road!

HALF-TIME: #watfordfc 2-0 Burnley
Great first 45 minutes from the Hornets! Jeff Hendrick was shown a straight red card for a two-footed tackle on Jose Holebas, leaving the Clarets down to 10 men after just six minutes. Troy Deeney capitalised with a 10th-minute header from M'Baye Niang's cross, then in stoppage time at the end of the half, the AC Milan loanee nodded home his first in Watford colours after Holebas' near-post delivery.
Matchday Live: www.watfordfc.com

TEAM NEWS: #watfordfc v Burnley
Two changes for the Hornets following their 2-1 win at Arsenal on Tuesday. Britos and Janmaat are replaced by Holebas and Zarate, who comes in for his Hornets debut.
HORNETS: Gomes (GK); Cathcart, Kaboul, Prödl, Holebas; Behrami; Niang, Cleverley, Capoue, Zarate; Deeney (c).
Subs: Arlauskis (GK), Britos, Janmaat, Watson, Doucouré, Success, Okaka.
CLARETS: Heaton (GK) (c); Lowton, Keane, Mee, Ward; Arfield, Hendrick, Barton, Boyd; Barnes, Gray.
Subs: Robinson (GK), Flanagan, Gudmundsson, Tarkowski, Brady, Westwood, Vokes.

FULL-TIME: Bournemouth 2-2 #watfordfc
Another draw between the Cherries and the Hornets. Christian Kabasele's first-half header had the visitors ahead at the break, but Josh King converted an equaliser from close-range shortly after the interval. Troy Deeney's header restored the lead with 64 minutes played, but Bournemouth sub Benik Afobe drilled home with eight minutes remaining to make it 2-2.
Matchday Live: www.watfordfc.com

HALF-TIME: Bournemouth 0-1 #watfordfc
Christian Kabasele's 23rd-minute header has the Hornets ahead at the break. The Belgian defender nodded home from close-range after Miguel Britos' header back across goal following a Jose Holebas corner.
Matchday Live: www.watfordfc.com

TEAM NEWS: Bournemouth v #watfordfc
One change for the Hornets this afternoon. Midfielder Tom Cleverley comes in for his first start since signing on loan from Everton, replacing Valon Behrami, who is recovering from injury. Daryl Janmaat returns to the bench following his injury picked up on Boxing Day.

FA CUP: Watford will be ball number 19 in the Fourth Round draw which takes place on Monday, January 9th, just after 7pm live on BT Sport and BBC Two. Tell us below who you'd like us to get in the next round!

FULL-TIME: #watfordfc 2-0 Burton Albion
The Hornets secure passage to the Fourth Round of the FA Cup courtesy of goals from Christian Kabasele and Jerome Sinclair either side of half-time.
Head to watfordfc.com for post-match reaction as we get it. Come on you 'Orns!

HALF-TIME: #watfordfc 1-0 Burton Albion
Full debutant Brandon Mason bagged an assist for Christian Kabaele's goal which separates the two sides at Vicarage Road.
It's been a quiet opening 45 minutes, Etienne Capoue's rasping drive and Ighalo's effort over the bar the only other chances of note.

TEAM NEWS: #watfordfc v Burton Albion
Live commentary at watfordfc.com now!
Brandon Mason makes his first start for the senior side after impressing as a substitute against Tottenham on New Years' Day.
Costel Pantilimon replaces Heurelho Gomes in goal as the Brazilian shot-stopper is sidelined through illness.
Jerome Sinclair and Odion Ighalo both start after coming off the bench against Stoke in the midweek Premier League fixture.
Craig Cathcart replaces Sebastian Prödl in the starting eleven as he looks to improve his match fitness after a long injury layoff.
HORNETS: Pantilimon (GK); Kaboul, Cathcart, Britos; Kabasele, Capoue, Doucouré, Mason; Sinclair, Ighalo; Deeney (c)

The hosts lead by one at the break courtesy of Pablo Zabaleta's strike.
Apart from a couple of Watford crosses from the right-hand side, Pep Guardiola's men have been well on top. But, it's still only 1-0, and while it stays that way the Hornets have a chance.

"There was no doubt who deserved the victory."
Walter Mazzarri says #watfordfc were good value for their 1-0 win over Hull City yesterday. He was also particularly pleased to see a return to action for Daryl Janmaat.
More here: http://bit.ly/MazzarriHullReaction

FULL-TIME: #watfordfc 1-0 Hull City
A fully deserved three points for the Hornets, who win thanks to a Michael Dawson own-goal with eight minutes to go. That's four games unbeaten for Watford, who have also kept three consecutive clean sheets.

HALF-TIME: #watfordfc 0-0 Hull City
Goalless at the break, but the Hornets have been the better side. Younes Kaboul and Roberto Pereyra both hit the woodwork during the opening stages, while Troy Deeney and Sebastian Prödl each saw headers go wide later in the half.

TEAM NEWS: #watfordfc v Hull Tigers
One change for the Hornets today as Nordin Amrabat replaces Camilo Zuniga at right wing-back. Daryl Janmaat is back on the bench after a shoulder injury.
HORNETS: Gomes (GK); Kaboul, Prödl, Britos; Amrabat, Pereyra, Behrami, Capoue, Holebas; Deeney (c), Ighalo.
Subs: Pantilimon (GK), Kabasele, Janmaat, Zuniga, Watson, Guedioura, Sinclair.
TIGERS: Marshall (GK), Maguire, Davies, Hernandez, Clucas, Livermore, Keane, Dawson (c), Henriksen, Mason, Elmohamady.
Subs: Jakupovic (GK), Meyler, Huddlestone, Maloney, Weir, Tymon, Bowen.

FULL-TIME: #watfordfc 2-2 Bournemouth
Troy Deeney hauled the Hornets level five minutes after the break with a close-range finish to Nordin Amrabat's cross, after Callum Wilson's first-half header.
Josh King restored Bournemouth's lead moments after his introduction from the bench, but it was another sub - in the shape of Isaac Success - who headed Watford's 65th-minute equaliser, his first goal for the Golden Boys.

HALF-TIME: #watfordfc 0-1 Bournemouth
The Cherries lead through Callum Wilson's 31st-minute header after a Junior Stanislas cross from the right-flank.
Nordin Amrabat went closest for the Hornets, with two efforts in quick succession which were saved by keeper Artur Boruc late in the half.

TEAM NEWS: #watfordfc v AFC Bournemouth
Two changes for the Hornets, with Camilo Zuniga and Younes Kaboul replacing Craig Cathcart (hip) and Miguel Britos (thigh).
Also missing this afternoon are Daryl Janmaat (shoulder), Adrian Mariappa (sickness), Stefano Okaka (hamstring) and Jerome Sinclair (hamstring).
HORNETS: Gomes (GK); Zuniga, Kaboul, Prödl, Holebas; Amrabat, Behrami, Capoue; Pereyra; Deeney (c), Ighalo.
Subs: Pantilimon (GK), Kabasele, Kenedy, Watson, Doucoure, Guedioura, Success.
CHERRIES: Boruc (GK); Smith, Cook, Francis (c), Daniels; Ibe, Wilshere, Arter, Surman, Stanislas; Wilson.
Subs: Federici (GK), Gosling, Ake, Afobe, Gradel, Smith, King.

FULL-TIME: Burnley 2-0 #watfordfc
It was a disappointing night in Lancashire as goals from corners in either half condemned Watford to a 2-0 defeat at the hands of newly-promoted Burnley.
Backed by an outstanding 1,415 travelling supporters, the Hornets failed to produce in front of the Monday Night Football TV cameras and fell to their first defeat on the road this season.
Jeff Hendrick headed the Clarets in-front late in the first-half, and Michael Keane scored via the same method five minutes after the break as the Golden Boys struggled to deal defensively with the visitors’ set-pieces.

HALF-TIME: Burnley 1-0 #watfordfc
Jeff Hendrick's 38th-minute header has given the Clarets a deserved lead at the break. The midfielder rose highest from a Steven Defour corner to nod inside the far post during a disappointing opening 45 minutes for the Hornets.

TEAM NEWS: #watfordfc v Burnley
One change for the Hornets following last weekend's win over Manchester United, with Nordin Amrabat replacing Daryl Janmaat (shoulder). Younes Kaboul is back on the bench after recovering from a hamstring problem.

SNAPSHOTS: Four great celebration shots as #watfordfc secured a memorable 3-1 win over Manchester United!

FULL-TIME: #watfordfc 3-1 Manchester United
The Hornets' first win over United in 30 years!
Marcus Rashford cancelled out Etienne Capoue's first-half opener just after the hour, but Walter Mazzarri's men battled on and super-sub Camilo Zuniga drilled into the bottom corner moments after his introduction to hand the Golden Boys a deserved 83rd-minute lead.
And there was more, Troy Deeney smashed home a stoppage time penalty after Marouane Fellaini's trip on Zuniga, sending the superb Watford fans into delirium.
An historic afternoon at The Vic!
Re-live all the action as it happened here: http://bit.ly/WFCMatchdayLive

HALF-TIME: #watfordfc 1-0 Manchester United
Etienne Capoue's fourth goal in five games has the Hornets ahead against Jose Mourinho's men at the break. The midfielder smashed home from inside the box after receiving a cut-back from Daryl Janmaat. It's no less than Watford deserve, with Odion Ighalo and Troy Deeney also going close.

FULL-TIME: #watfordfc 1-3 Arsenal
A much-improved second-half showing from the Hornets, with half-time substitute Pereyra scoring a debut goal 57 minutes in, hooking home after Capoue's initial effort had been blocked. But the damage was done before the break, Cazorla's penalty and goals from Alexis and Ozil firing the Gunners into a three-goal lead.

HALF-TIME: #watfordfc 0-3 Arsenal
The Gunners took a controversial ninth-minute lead when Cazorla slotted home a penalty after Amrabat was ruled to have fouled Alexis in the area. That advantage was doubled by Alexis, whose shot just crossed the line following a 40th-minute Walcott cross, and in stoppage time at the end of the first-half Ozil ghosted into the box to head home a third.

FULL-TIME (AET): #watfordfc 1-2 Gillingham
The Hornets exit the EFL Cup in the second round after falling to League One side Gillingham at The Vic.
Odion Ighalo handed the Hornets a 58th-minute lead, two minutes after his introduction as a substitute, and then Bradley Dack skied a penalty as the Gills threatened to equalise.
They were level with eight minutes to go though, Mark Byrne finding the bottom corner with a curling effort which sent the game into extra-time.
Dack atoned for his earlier spot-kick miss with 102 minutes played, bundling marginally over the line from close-range to send the visitors through to the third round.

HALF-TIME: #watfordfc 0-0 Gillingham
Honours even at the break during tonight's EFL Cup Round Two game. Watford have had the better of the chances, but are yet to find a breakthrough. Gills keeper Stuart Nelson has produced a few important saves, keeping out Troy Deeney, Ikechi Anya and Matej Vydra chances.

Subs: Gomes (GK), Kaboul, Holebas, Zuniga, Capoue, Sinclair, Ighalo.

GALLERY: Here are some action shots from #watfordfc's 2-1 defeat to Chelsea at The Vic this afternoon.

FULL-TIME: #watfordfc 1-2 Chelsea
The visitors take all three points after coming back from 1-0 down late on. Etienne Capoue blasted the Hornets into the lead with a superb left-footed volley in the 55th minute, but Chelsea sub Michy Batshuayi equalised from close-range with 10 minutes to go after Heurelho Gomes couldn't hold on to Eden Hazard's low shot. Diego Costa scored the winner in the 87th minute, slotting home after a long ball over the Hornets' defence.

HALF-TIME: #watfordfc 0-0 Chelsea
Good first 45 minutes for the Hornets, who had the chance of the half when Odion Ighalo turned just over from close-range after Nordin Amrabat beat Cesar Azpilicueta down the right and delivered an inch-perfect cross.
